content.raw:
Thanks for the report. I hope you don't mind if I ask a few questions about your setup:

* It looks like you are using gzclient 7.4.0 on macOS. Does that version of gzclient work with its corresponding gzserver?
* What version of gzserver is being used within the docker container?
* Can you verify that gzserver is working inside the docker container after loading gzserver in the background with the following commands?

~~~
gzserver --verbose your.world &
gz stats
gz topic -l
~~~

* Can you run the `gz stats` and `gz topic -l` commands from macOS while the gzserver is running in the docker container?
content.html:
Thanks for the report. I hope you don't mind if I ask a few questions about your setup:

  • It looks like you are using gzclient 7.4.0 on macOS. Does that version of gzclient work with its corresponding gzserver?
  • What version of gzserver is being used within the docker container?
  • Can you verify that gzserver is working inside the docker container after loading gzserver in the background with the following commands?
gzserver --verbose your.world &
gz stats
gz topic -l
  • Can you run the gz stats and gz topic -l commands from macOS while the gzserver is running in the docker container?

content.raw:
Thank you for the quick answer @scpeters.

The server also runs 7.4.0.
I can do `gz topic -l` on the client and it produces the same output on the server as on the client
But on the client `gz stats` has no output for long and then like gzclient produces the same mutex lock error. 

On the server both commands run fine. 
Is there communication happening on a port other than 11345 that I am maybe blocking so that this communication of `gz stats` doesn't happen?
content.html:
Thank you for the quick answer @scpeters.

The server also runs 7.4.0. I can do gz topic -l on the client and it produces the same output on the server as on the client But on the client gz stats has no output for long and then like gzclient produces the same mutex lock error.

On the server both commands run fine. Is there communication happening on a port other than 11345 that I am maybe blocking so that this communication of gz stats doesn't happen?

content.raw:
Ok, so you can do `gz topic -l`, but not `gz stats`. I thought all comms happen on port 11345, but here's a few more things to try:

Can you try the following (may need to change the topic to match the world name you are using):

~~~
gz topic -i /gazebo/default/world_stats
gz topic -e /gazebo/default/world_stats -d 0
gz topic -e /gazebo/default/world_stats -d 1
~~~

If one of those fails, can you get its backtrace too?
content.html:
Ok, so you can do gz topic -l, but not gz stats. I thought all comms happen on port 11345, but here's a few more things to try:

Can you try the following (may need to change the topic to match the world name you are using):

gz topic -i /gazebo/default/world_stats
gz topic -e /gazebo/default/world_stats -d 0
gz topic -e /gazebo/default/world_stats -d 1

If one of those fails, can you get its backtrace too?

content.raw:
So `-d 0` produces no output. 
`-d 1` there is no output for long and then `-d 1` and then terminates with the same mutex error. It also produces the console log that follows.
![Bildschirmfoto 2016-10-27 um 09.58.33.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/83778016-Bildschirmfoto_2016-10-27_um_09.58.33.png)

`gz topic -i /gazebo/default/world_stats` works and has the following output:

```
Type: gazebo.msgs.WorldStatistics

Publishers:
	172.17.0.2:35292

Subscribers:
```
content.html:
So -d 0 produces no output. -d 1 there is no output for long and then -d 1 and then terminates with the same mutex error. It also produces the console log that follows.

gz topic -i /gazebo/default/world_stats works and has the following output:

    172.17.0.2:35292

Subscribers:

content.raw:
Do you have any other idea that I could look into, @scpeters? 
If you want to test it on your machine, I can share you the exact docker image I use as a server.
